theme.title: Anacrusis (upbeat, pickup notes)
theme.para: In this lesson we continue studying the strong and weak parts (accented and unstressed parts) of the measure.
In all the examples and exercises seen so far, the pieces began with the first note located in the first part of the measure, which is always stressed. For example:

score.music: (score (vers 1.6) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C)(time 2 4) (n g4 q)(n e4 e g+)(n f4 e g-) (barline) (n g4 q)(n c5 q) (barline) (n b4 q) (barline end noVisible) )))

theme.para: But it doesn't always have to be this way. A piece of music (or a musical phrase) can begin both in a strong part of the measure or in a weak part. When a piece of music (or a phrase) begins in a weak part or in a weak fraction it is said that it begins in upbeat or in anacrusis. The anacrusis is often called a pickup, pickup note, or pickup measure. Examples:

score.music: (score (vers 1.6) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C)(time 2 4) (n c5 e) (barline) (n c5 e g+)(n b4 e g-)(n c5 e g+)(n a4 e g-) (barline) (n g4 q) (barline end noVisible) )))
(score (vers 1.6) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C)(time 4 4) (n e4 e)(n a4 e g+)(n b4 e g-) (barline) (n c5 q)(n c5 e g+)(n c5 e g-)(n e5 q) (barline end noVisible) )))
(score (vers 1.6) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C)(time 3 4) (n a4 e g+)(n b4 e g-) (barline) (n c5 q)(n a4 q)(n c5 q) (barline) (n b4 q)(n e4 q) (barline end noVisible) )))

theme.para: We could define the anacrusis as: 'note or group of notes that precede the first downbeat of a piece or a musical phrase'. If you look closely, you will notice that the pickup always precedes the first measure of the piece or of the musical phrase. Also note that in the upbeat beginning, as the first note is in a weak part or fraction, the rests that precede the first note are not included at the beginning of the piece, so it 'seems' an incomplete measure. Also, this 'incomplete' measure is not counted when numbering the measures. For example:

score.music: (score (vers 2.0) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C)(time 4 4) (text _''Anacrusis of'' (dx -50)(dy -40))(text _''measure 1'' (dx -30)(dy -20)) (n e4 e g+)(n f4 e g-) (barline) (text _''measure 1'' (dx 10)(dy 80)) (n g4 q)(n e4 e g+)(n f4 e g-) (n g4 q)(n g4 e g+)(n a4 e g-) (barline) (text _''measure 2'' (dx 10)(dy 80)) (n g4 q)(n e4 q)(n c4 q)(n c4 e g+)(n d4 e g-) (barline) (text _''measure 3'' (dx 10)(dy 80)) (text _''Anacrusis of'' (dx 120)(dy -40))(text _''measure 4'' (dx 150)(dy -20)) (n c4 h)(r e)(n g4 e)(n a4 e g+)(n b4 e g-) (barline) (text _''measure 4'' (dx 10)(dy 80)) (n c5 q)(n a4 q)(n f4 q)(n f4 e g+)(n a4 e g-) (barline) (text _''measure 5'' (dx 10)(dy 80)) (n d5 q)(n b4 q)(n c5 q)(n b4 e g+)(n a4 e g-) (barline) (text _''measure 6'' (dx 10)(dy 80)) (n g4 q)(n g4 e g+)(n a4 e g-)(n g4 e g+)(n +f4 e g-) (barline) (text _''measure 7'' (dx 10)(dy 80)) (n g4 h)(r h) (barline end noVisible) )))

theme.para: To practice counting and reading when a piece starts in upbeat, you have to analyze that initial measure, imagine the missing rests at the beginning, needed for completing the measure, and do the reading starting as usual at the first beat of the measure but taking into account those missing rest and reading them.
